title: 112_s3436
content: The Act is titled the "Infant and Toddler Care Improvement Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The brain undergoes significant development in a child's first 3 years, forming crucial capacities. Economic deprivation can impact brain development, especially in children below the poverty line. Child care plays a vital role in early development for many infants. High-quality child care is crucial for the early development of infants and toddlers, especially for at-risk children under 3 years old. Research shows that it can mitigate the effects of poverty and lead to better developmental outcomes. High-quality child care promotes positive cognitive, language, and social development, contributing to academic success. Training and assistance for infant and toddler care providers improve caregiver quality in 27 states through specialist networks using research-based techniques like mentoring and coaching. Only 21 states have specific training requirements for infant and toddler care providers, recognizing the unique needs of children under 3 years old. However, not all states have regulations or quality indicators tailored to infants and toddlers in their child care systems. Only 20 states include infant and toddler quality indicators in their Quality Rating and Improvement Systems, and just 3 states have separate regulations for infant and toddler care. The purpose of this Act is to improve the quality of child care programs for infants and toddlers by implementing separate regulations for their care. SEC. 658H. HIGH-QUALITY INFANT AND TODDLER CARE PROGRAM. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section focusing on high-quality care for infants and toddlers. In this section, definitions are provided for terms related to infant and toddler care, including eligible providers, age range, and developmental delays or disabilities. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to infant and toddler care, such as limited English proficient, low-income community, and low-income family. It also outlines the grants that the Secretary shall make to eligible States to improve the quality of care for infants and toddlers. The Secretary reserves amounts for payments to territories, Indian tribes, and possessions under this section for each fiscal year. The Secretary reserves amounts for payments to territories, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations with approved applications. The remaining funds are allotted to states based on a proportional relationship to the amount allotted under section 658O. The term 'State' excludes Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the. A State receiving a grant under this section must include in its plan a description of how funds will be used to improve infant and toddler care quality. The funds must be used for activities such as making grants to eligible entities to enhance early childhood education quality. The grant aims to improve early care and development services for infants and toddlers from low-income families by assisting eligible child care providers who meet specific quality standards. The grant prioritizes funding for child care providers that meet high-quality program standards and serve low-income families. The grant prioritizes funding for child care providers serving low-income families, with a focus on entities located in low-income communities, those serving populations with limited English proficiency, and those enhancing caregiver abilities to coordinate services for children with developmental delays. The State can use funds to establish staffed family child care networks providing technical assistance, training, and support to eligible infant and toddler care providers. The State can prioritize organizations supporting a statewide network of infant and toddler specialists using grant funds. These specialists provide training and support to eligible infant and toddler care providers. The State prioritizes organizations that provide training and support to infant and toddler care providers, including coordinating activities with other child care offices. State funds can be used to support initiatives that improve the quality of infant and toddler care providers, such as training and professional development programs. State funds can be used to support initiatives that improve the quality of infant and toddler care providers, including providing scholarships, coordinating with higher education systems, and improving state credentialing. State funds can be used to improve the quality of infant and toddler care providers by enhancing State credentialing, developing components for Quality Rating and Improvement Systems, providing information to parents, and assisting providers in increasing their ranking on the State's quality system. The State can use funds to enhance infant and toddler care quality through various initiatives, such as meeting performance standards, accreditation, and other activities determined by the State to improve safety, development, and well-being. Reporting requirements apply to States receiving grants for these purposes. The State must report on how funding is used to improve infant and toddler care quality and its impact. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2013 and beyond. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to sections 658B and 658O(a)(1) of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990.
